Different types of silica (mesoporous, spherical and nano-size particles), pre-activated with methylaluminoxane (MAO), are used to activate and support the bis[N-(3‑tert-butylsalicydene)-2,3,4,5,6-pentafluoroanilinato] titanium(IV) dichloride (FI) complex with the aim to synthesize low-entangled UHMWPE having controlled particle morphology. Through the porosity analysis, nitrogen adsorption and desorption isotherms, a decreased surfaced area of the chosen silica is observed when supported by MAO. From the bonding energy study by XPS, the bonding energy difference of Si and O, between the nano-size silica and in the MAO-nano silica, suggests the formation of Al-O-Si after chemical activation with MAO. Using elementary analysis, ICP-OES and XPS characterization, the aluminum content grafted on the silica surface is found to match with the anticipated amount of MAO on the MAO-Silica/FI catalytic system, indicating a stable grafting after catalyst supporting. From the rheological studies of the polymers, coupled with DSC results using an isothermal crystallization protocol, the resultant entangled state in the semi-crystalline polymers is estimated. The observations are that the entangled state achieved during polymerization from the investigated heterogeneous catalytic systems, is the lowest in PE-MAO-nano silica/FI, increases in PE-MAO-mesoporous silica/FI and is highest in PE-MAO-spherical silica/FI. Silica modification using two different silanes shows significant influence on the catalytic activity, giving lower polymer yield in MAO-modified-mesoporous silica and MAO-modified-nano silica compared to the unmodified MAO-silica. Whereas, no significant spatial effect is observed in the formation of chain entanglement, showing the increased entanglement density of the nascent polymers. By employing heterogeneous catalytic systems, reactor fouling and wall sheeting problems are resolved and the polymers show good morphology replication of the support. The UHMWPE synthesized using the nano silica as support, having the lowest entangled state and loosely packed crystals, can be uniaxially processed in the solid-state to a thin tape having thickness around 34 μm, showing maximum tensile strength of 3.26 N/tex and tensile modulus of 170 N/tex. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords UHMWPE Heterogeneous Supporting FI catalyst Entanglement Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Commercial ultra-high molecular weight polyethylene (UHMWPE) is synthesized using a heterogeneous catalyst (so-called Ziegler-Natta consisting of TiCl3 or TiCl4 supported on MgCl2 and modified by different organic molecules called donors) at relatively high polymerization temperatures (e.g. above 60–80 °C), using a polymerization medium, in slurry phase. In the majority of the cases, polymerization conditions are optimized to maximize the catalyst productivity without focusing on the polymer crystallization. To enhance the commercially desired catalyst activity, the active sites density on the heterogeneous Ziegler-Natta catalytic systems is increased to an extent that neighboring growing chains entangle significantly, prior to crystallization. Moreover, with higher polymerization temperatures used (decrease in the supercooling), the crystallization rate decreases. Thus, the commercial UHMWPE samples possess large number of entanglements in the non-crystalline region of the semi-crystalline polymer formed during the polymer synthesis. The large number of entanglements are the responsible for the extreme melt viscosity of the polymer melt limiting its processing. Retrospectively, the commercial sample cannot be processed in the solid-state. The current processing route for the entangled UHMWPE make use of nearly 90 wt.% of toxic solvent, with the aim to reduce the entanglement density prior to deformation in the solid-state [1–5]. In contrast to the commercial entangled UHMWPE [6–8], the low-entangled UHMWPE particles, synthesized using a homogeneous catalytic system (consists of bis(phenoxy-imine) titanium dichloride complex (FI catalyst) and methylaluminoxane (MAO)), under the controlled conditions, can be easily compressed below the melting temperature (125 °C). Followed by rolling and stretching process, solid-state drawn tapes have unprecedented tensile modulus exceeding 200 GPa (solution spun commercial fibers, 130 GPa) and tensile strength above 4.0 GPa (solution spun commercial fiber, 3.5 GPa) [7]. The economically attractive and environmental friendly solid-state processing route, in combination with the resultant unprecedented mechanical properties of the uniaxial and biaxial drawn tapes and films, is a unique disruptive technology that necessitates commercialization as the demand of the UHMWPE products for societal requirement is increasing annually (> 10% cumulative annual growth rate) [6,8,9,10]. Other homogeneous catalytic systems are also reported to promote the polymerization of ethylene to low entangled UHMWPE which can be solid-state processed to achieve high tensile modulus and strength [11–13]. However, homogeneous polymerization cannot be a route for commercialization as it suffers from serious reactor fouling and uncontrolled polymer morphology, limiting this synthetic route to the lab scale. To tackle this technical problem, heterogeneous catalytic systems (e.g. the catalyst is not soluble in the reaction media) are needed to avoid reactor fouling and wall sheeting [14,15]. Few studies are reported on the synthesis of low-entangled UHMWPE are reported on supporting FI catalyst. To recall, in 2012, Ronca et al. used nanoparticles TiO2, hydroxyapatite, SWCNT-OH and ZrO2 as the support, coupling with FI catalyst bis[N-(3-tert-butylsalicydene)-2,3,4,5,6-pentafluoroanilinato] titanium(IV) dichloride by MAO, for ethylene polymerization. They found that the chosen route for heterogeneous catalytic system considerably suppresses the reactor fouling compared with the homogeneous polymerization as illustrated in the Fig. 1 [16]. The resulting polymer can be processed in solid-state to obtain high modulus high tensile strength tapes, though the resulting mechanical properties were found to be considerably lower than those obtained using homogeneous conditions. Later on, Li et al. reported different functionalized (polyhedral oligomeric silsesquioxane, POSS) silica nanoparticles as support to study the compatibility between UHMWPE and nanoparticles and the influence of the nanoparticles on the polymerization activity. They found that the presence of POSS decreases the catalytic activity of the active sites. However, the route could be used to disperse POSS nanoparticles homogeneously in the intractable UHMWPE matrix [17,18]. Furthermore, the authors supported the catalyst on the POSS-modified silica and pointed out that POSS acted as spacers for the active sites reducing the entanglement density of the produced UHMWPE [19]. Meanwhile, Ferreira and coworkers have studied the influence of different catalyst preparation procedures on the polymerization activity. They used mesoporous SBA-15 silica as catalyst support and prepared the catalytic system in different ways finding that the pre-activated catalyst/SBA-15 had better activity in ethylene polymerization, which was almost three times lower than the homogeneous catalytic system [20]. Afterwards, Barrera and coworkers used organic groups-modified silica as a support to immobilize the FI catalyst, finding that the organic group appeared to act as a modifier (horizontal spacer) around the active sites affecting the activity and kinetics involved in polymerization while using the catalyst [21]. Within the above investigated bis(phenoxy-imine) titanium dichloride-based heterogeneous catalytic system, the studies have mostly focused on investigating the activity of heterogeneous catalytic system, but barely on relationship between the supports’ feature (i.e. dimensions, porosity) and MAO which was consequently related to the entanglement density of synthesized UHMWPE polymers. It is known that the different support features affect the catalyst supporting and special spacing of the same, thus influencing the particle morphology as well as the resultant entangled state of the polymer produced, which in turns, dictates the ability of being solid-state process and influence the mechanical properties of the uniaxially solid-state processed tapes. The silicas used in this work have been chosen based on their different features in terms of surface area, size and porosity. For example, two mesoporous silica are chosen to test the possibility of spreading the active sites within the pores of the silica, leading to less chain overlap between the growing chains prior to crystallization (less entanglement). Moreover, different silica sizes from nano to micro are chosen with the intention of controlling the number of active sites supported per silica particle, hence, reducing the chain overlap during the ethylene polymerization. In this work, we have used different types of thermally dehydrated silica (mesoporous silica, spherical silica, silica nano powder) as support for anchoring the MAO. The MAO activated silica is used to support the bis[N-(3-tert-butylsalicydene)-2,3,4,5,6-pentafluoroanilinato] titanium(IV) dichloride complex and the resulting supported catalysts are tested for the ethylene polymerization. The influence of support on the catalyst activity, resultant entanglement density and the morphology of the synthesized polymer is investigated in this work. The pore structure of silicas and MAO-silicas are studied by nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherm (BET method). The MAO grafting, bonds and grafting quantification of the MAO and FI catalyst over the silica are characterized by inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES), and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). Catalytic systems and the polymer particle morphology are examined by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and the entanglement density of the synthesized polymers are studied by a combination of DSC and parallel-plate melt rheometry. To follow the influence of entanglement on the growing chain, two different sizes of modifiers (ethyltrimethoxysilane and octadecyltrichlorosilane) are used as potential spacers on silica. The route is adopted to investigate the influence of organic groups on the polymerization activity and the entanglement density of polymers. Solid-state processability of the most promising polymer has been tested. 2 Experimental part 2.1 Materials Anhydrous diethyl ether, n-Butyl lithium (2.5 M in hexane), anhydrous hexane, 2,3,4,5,6-pentafluoroaniline (99%) and titanium (IV) chloride (99%) were purchased from Sigma Aldrich and used as received. Anhydrous toluene and anhydrous THF were purchased from LPS and further purified using a solvent purifier systems (MBraun SPS compact). p-toluenesulfonic acid (12 wt.% in acetic acid) and 3-tert-butyl-2-hydroxybenzaldehyde were purchased from Acros Organics and used as received. CDCl3 was purchased from Cambridge Isotope Laboratories and dried over molecular sieves. Dichloromethane was purchased from Sigma Aldrich and was dried and stored over molecular sieves prior to use. MAO was purchased from Albemarle (30 wt.% in toluene). Irganox1010 was purchased from BASF. Grade 3.5 ethylene was purchased from Linde. Ethyltrimethoxysilane and octadecyltrichlorosilane were purchased from Acros Organics and used as received. Mesoporous silicas (SBA-15, pore size of 8 nm (named S1) and pore size of 4 nm (named S2)) were purchased from Sigma Aldrich. Spherical silica with particle size around 130 μm, (named S3) was purchased from Alfa Aesar. Spherical silica with particle size around 60 μm, (named S4) was purchased from SUPELCO. Silica nanopowder (named S5) was purchased from Sigma Aldrich. All the silicas were thermally dehydrated at 200 °C under vacuum for 22 h prior to use. The particle information (surface area, pore size, average particle size) of the used silicas were provided by the commercial resource and reproduced in Table 1 . All manipulations of air and moisture-sensitive compounds were performed under nitrogen atmosphere, using Schlenk-techniques or in the glovebox (MBraun, UNIlab plus). 2.2 Preparation of catalytic system 2.2.1 Silica activation [22,23] Silicas were first thermally treated at 200 °C under vacuum for 22 h to remove the absorbed moisture. Silicas modification: 1 g of thermally treated silica was added into 30 ml of anhydrous toluene, followed by the addition of the required amount of modifier (nOH:nmodifier=3:1) under constant mixing in refluxing conditions for 19 h. The resulting suspension was then filtered and the solid was washed three times with 30 ml of anhydrous toluene. The resulting silica-modifier white solid particles were dried under nitrogen flow and stored in the glovebox for further use (named as modified Silica, mSilica; with small modifier-ethyltrimethoxysilane, smSilica; with big modifier-octadecyltrichlorosilane, bmSilica). Silicas chemical grafting with MAO: 1 g thermally activated/modified silica was added into 30 ml of anhydrous toluene at 50 °C, the required amount of MAO (mMAO solution/mSiO2=2) was introduced for chemical activation under continuous stirring for 19 h. The resulting suspension was filtered and the solid was washed for three times with 30 ml of anhydrous toluene. The resultant white silica-MAO solid particles were dried under nitrogen flow (named as chemically grafted Silica, MAO-Silica and MAO-smSilica, MAO-bmSilica). 2.2.2 Catalyst synthesis The FI catalyst, bis[N-(3-tert-butylsalicydene)-2,3,4,5,6-pentafluoroanilinato] titanium(IV) dichloride, was synthesized according to reported procedures, as stated in Supporting information S1 [24,25]. The catalytic system was prepared by the mixture of 400 mg MAO-Silica or MAO-mSilica with 15 mg of FI catalyst in 4 ml of dry toluene. 2.2.3 Ethylene polymerization The polymerization was conducted in a Büchi 1.5 L metal reactor vessel, equipped with a thermometer probe, injection port, N2/vacuum valve, pressure transducer, monomer feeding port, solvent feeding port and a Buchi cyclone 300 stirrer with 4-bladed propeller. The reactor was firstly heated to 125 °C overnight in vacuo. Afterwards, at least three N2/vacuum cycles were performed to clean the reactor from possible impurities and left under positive nitrogen pressure. Then, the temperature was set to 10 °C and 750 ml of anhydrous toluene was transferred under constant stirring rate of 750 rpm. After temperature equilibration, the nitrogen was replaced with ethylene at the absolute pressure of 1.1 bar using a press-flow Buchi bpc 2 controller. In a glovebox, 400 mg activated silica was introduced in a Schlenk vial and mixed with 4 ml of dried toluene followed by the addition of 15 mg of catalyst. Then, polymerization reaction was started by the addition of the suspension to the reaction vessel under ethylene flow and quickly followed by setting the ethylene pressure to 2 bar. The polymerization was terminated after 60 min by venting the monomer and adding 10 ml of ethanol. The polymer was washed with ethanol and acetone and subsequently dried at 40 °C in vacuo overnight. The preparation for homogeneous polymerization can be found in reference 25. Once dried, 0.7–1.0 wt.% of Irganox1010 (antioxidant) was added to the polymer. 2.3 Characterization 2.3.1 Scanning electron microscope and energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy SEM measurements were performed on Philips-XL 30 equipped with SED (secondary electron detector) and EDAX energy dispersive x-ray detector under 10 KV. The sample was evenly sprayed on the carbon tape sticking on the stage and coated with gold around 30 s for measuring. 2.3.2 Nitrogen adsorption and desorption analysis The surface area and pore size were determined by nitrogen adsorption analyses at 77 K on a Micrometrics ASAP 2420 BET instrument. The samples around 80 mg were degassed prior to analysis for 12 h at 60 °C under high vacuum. Because of the presence of MAO on the silica, degassing at higher temperatures was not possible. The surface area calculation were done using Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) model applied from the nitrogen adsorption branch of the isotherm in the relative pressure range P/Po of 0.05–0.3. Pore size distribution was calculated using non-local density functional theory model. 2.3.3 Inductively couples plasma-optical emission spectroscopy The Al and Ti amount in catalytic system have been determined by ICP-OES measurements. The samples around 30 mg were firstly digested by a mixture of 5 mL hydrogen chloride (HCl), 2 mL nitric acid (HNO3), and 1 mL hydrogen fluoride with Milestone's ultraWAVE (Single Reactor Chamber Microwave Digestion System). The measurement was carried out using Agilent 5110 ICP-OES. A calibration curve was prepared prior to analysis. The digested samples were diluted with distilled water and standard samples prepared with 1 wt.% HNO3 in water. 2.3.4 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy The surface bonding of the catalytic systems were studied by XPS measurements. The samples were scattered on the sample stage through a tape in the glovebox and transferred with a specially designed vacuum module, because the compounds are air/moisture sensitive. XPS experiments were performed on a Kratos Axis ULTRA instrument equipped with a monochromatic Al Kα X-ray source (hν = 1486.6 eV) operated at 75 W under pressure of 10–9 mbar. The spectra were recorded in a hybrid mode using electrostatic and magnetic lenses and an aperture slot of 300 by 700 µm. The survey and high-resolution spectra were acquired at fixed analyzer pass energies of 80 eV and 20 eV respectively. The samples were mounted in a floating mode to avoid differential charging and thus the spectra were acquired under charge neutralization conditions. 2.3.5 Thermogravimetric analysis The weight loss of the polymers by temperature were determined by TGA Q500 from TA instruments. Approximately 3 mg of polymer was heated from 50 to 500 °C at 10 °C/min followed by an isothermal step for 30 min at 500 °C under nitrogen flow. 2.3.6 Differential scanning calorimetry measurement A DSC250 from TA Instrument was used for the thermal analysis of polymers. For each sample, 1.5 ± 0.1 mg polymer was weighed in a T-zero aluminum pan and covered/crimped with a T-zero aluminum lid. During the measurement, nitrogen flow with a purge rate of 50 ml/min was used to prevent thermal degradation. Standard DSC protocol: In all the procedure, heating and cooling ramps were performed at 10 °C/min. A first heating step from 50 °C to 160 °C at the rate of 10 °C/min provided the melting temperature and melting enthalpy of the nascent powder. Once the temperature reached 160 °C, an isothermal step at 160 °C for 3 min was applied. Following, a cooling ramp from 160 °C to 50 °C was performed, providing the crystallization temperature and crystallization enthalpy, followed by a second isothermal step for 3 min. The heating and cooling cycles were repeated to provide the melting and crystallization temperatures of the melt-crystallized polymer. The crystallinity ( χ ) value was calculated according to the following: (1) χ = Δ H m Δ H 0 * 100 % where ΔHm represents the melting enthalpy of the nascent powder and ΔH0 represents the theoretical melting enthalpy of 100% crystalline polyethylene (293 J/g) [26]. Isothermal crystallization DSC protocol: Entanglement density of the nascent polymers were evaluated based on the ability of the disentangled domain in the melt to crystallize at lower supercooling compared to the entangled domains [27]. The DSC experimental protocol used is graphically visualized in Scheme 1 . 2.3.7 Rheology measurements To prevent thermal degradation during the long rheological experiments, 0.7–1.0 wt.% of Irganox1010 was added to the nascent powder. 700 mg of mixture was weighed to prepare the disk for rheological measurements. The disk was prepared using a round metal mold with a diameter of 35 mm. The mold was subjected at 125 °C for 5 min at 10 bar, then 10 min at 50 bar and lastly 5 min at 100 bar; afterwards the mold is cooled to room temperature under a load of 10 bar. The required 12 mm disk was obtained using a punching device. The rheology measurement was performed on a Discover Hybrid Rheometer 1 from TA Instrument using 12 mm disposable parallel plates. The temperature was set and regulated using a convection oven under constant nitrogen flow to prevent thermo-oxidative degradation. At room temperature, the parallel plate alignment was checked and then the temperature was set to 160 °C to zero the gap at the operating temperature. Afterwards, the temperature was reduced to 110 °C and the sample was inserted between the plates followed by a temperature ramp to 130 °C at 10 °C/min under a constant strain of 0.1%, constant axial force of 1 N and fixed oscillation frequency of 10 rad/s. After thermal stabilization, the temperature was set to 160 °C at 10 °C/min under a constant strain of 0.1%, constant axial force of 4 N and fixed oscillation frequency of 10 rad/s. From this point, the temperature and the axial force were not changed. After waiting 90 s for the temperature stabilization, an oscillating amplitude sweep test (strain range from 0.05% to 1.5%) was carried out to determine the linear viscoelastic regime. The oscillating time sweep test was performed to follow the entanglement formation with time at fixed frequency of 10 rad/s under small amplitude strain chosen within the linear viscoelastic regime of the polymer. After the polymers reached the equilibrium state (the storage modulus is independent with the time), a second oscillating amplitude sweep test was performed to check the linear viscoelastic regime at the equilibrium, followed by an oscillation frequency sweep from 600 rad/s to 10−4 rad/s within the linear viscoelastic regime. The value of Mw and Ð can be calculated by the commercial TA Instrument Orchestrator software based on the computational method developed by mead by fitting the viscoelastic functions as a function of oscillatory frequency [28]. With the aim to determine Mw and Ð only, the polymers were annealed at 160 °C for 24 h under vacuum prior to the hot compaction (performed then at 160 °C) to speed-up the equilibration process according to previous findings [10]. 2.3.8 Polymer processing and mechanical testing Solid state processing of the synthesized samples has been performed following the literature reported protocols with changes whenever required [7,16]. Using a Collin hot press P300s, 12.5 g of nascent powder is compression molded below the peak melting temperature using a stainless steel mold with a cavity of 29.5 cm in length and 30.2 mm in width to obtain a sintered strip of the same dimensions. The uniformly dispersed nascent powder is compressed at 130 °C, under a load of 125 kN for 30 min. The resulting sheet of ∼1.6 mm thickness is preheated at 120 °C and rolled with a Collin roll mill W 150 P at 130 °C (diameter rolls, 150 mm; gap distance, 0.15 mm, rolling speed 0.5 m/min). While rolling, the sheet is partially stretched to an approximately draw ratio of 12. The determination of the draw ratio is based on the length of the stretched and unstretched tapes. In particular, the draw ratio is calculated following the equation: D r a w R a t i o = L s t r e t c h e d L i n i t i a l Where Lstreched is the length of the tape after stretched and Linitial is the length of the original tape before stretched. The rolled-stretched sheet is further stretched in two steps on a custom made stretching device using a 90 cm long hot plate at the desired stretching temperature. The higher stretching temperature, above the peak melting temperature, is used for the partially stretched samples to transfer the macroscopic forces to the molecular level. To recall, the melting point of the partially stretched linear UHMWPE tapes can be suppressed under external constraint. The draw ratio is obtained by dividing the mass per unit length (linear density) of the sheet prior to deformation by the mass per unit length (linear density) of the tape after stretching. The sample is stretched to the desired draw ratio in the first stretching step. Afterwards, parts of this drawn sample obtained in the first stretch step, are used to measure the mechanical properties, whereas the remainder of the sample is drawn further to achieve the final draw ratios. The mechanical properties of the obtained tapes are determined as a function of the draw ratio achieved in all the stretching steps. 2.3.9 Determination of the mechanical properties by tensile testing Tensile properties were measured according to ASTM D7744−2011 using a Zwick-Roell Z010 tensile testing machine at room temperature (25 °C). To avoid any slippage, the side action grip clamps with flat jaw faces are used. The nominal gage length of the specimen is 100 mm, and the test is performed at a constant rate of extension (crosshead travel rate) of 100 mm/min. The breaking tenacity (or specific strength) and modulus (segment between 0.3 and 0.4 N/tex) are determined from the force against displacement between the jaws. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Characterization of catalytic systems Silica surface usually contains a significant amount of silanol groups, which are found as vicinal, geminal or isolated pairs [23]. This hydroxylated surface of the silica is responsible for its hygroscopic nature. From a catalytic perspective, the presence of silanol groups and moisture affect the catalyst or catalyst activator anchoring, hence, significantly influencing the resulting catalyst activity. The moisture physically absorbed on the surface is believed to be detrimental for the catalyst or co-catalyst anchoring due to incapability of producing a covalent bond with the silica and hence susceptible of leaching. For the catalyst/catalyst activator anchoring, the silanol groups are preferred, while the moisture is usually removed by thermal treatment. It is reported that the thermal treatment protocol influences the number and type of silanol groups available on the surfaces. In particular, for temperature between 100 and 200 °C, the water absorbed is removed; increasing the temperature to approximately 400–450 °C, vicinal and geminal silanol groups are mostly reduced, while for temperature above 600 °C is possible to reduce the total concentration of silanol groups until achieving a silanol concentration of approximately 1 OH/nm2 [22,29,30]. Therefore, to reduce the moisture and tailoring the number of hydroxyl groups, the silicas used (S1, S2, two mesoporous silica having different pore size of 4 and 8 nm; S3, S4, spherical silica having different particle size of 130 and 60 μm; S5, silica nanopowder) are thermally treated prior to their use. To choose an appropriate dehydroxylation temperature for the silica thermal activation, two temperatures of 200 and 600 °C have been used for three types of the silica (S1, S4, and S5). In order to verify the effect of the thermal treatment on the silicas, Fourier-transformed-Infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy is performed on the as-received silica and the thermally treated silicas at 200 °C for 22 h (Figure S9). From the FT-IR characterization, we observe a decrease of the broad peak around 3400 cm−1 attributed to physisorbed water; however, we also observe a decrease of the peak at 961 cm−1 which is attributed to the free silanol groups of the silica. Afterwards, the catalyst activator (MAO) is chemically grafted on the thermally activated silicas by reaction of the silanol groups with MAO [22,23,31]. The MAO-chemically grafted silicas are named as MAO-Silicas. Later on, the MAO-Silicas are then mixed with the FI catalyst and named as MAO-Silicas/FI, used for the ethylene polymerization. A higher yield is measured for the catalytic systems mesoporous silica and nano silica (S1 and S5) with thermally activated silica at lower temperature (200 °C, as shown in Figure S2). For this reason, 200 °C is chosen for the silica thermal activation process in the further studies. The porosity of the MAO-Silica are investigated by nitrogen adsorption and desorption analysis. The nitrogen adsorption and desorption curves are plotted in Fig. 2 , the surface area and pore volume are summarized in Table 2 . The aluminum and titanium content of the MAO-Silica and the MAO-Silica/FI are determined by ICP-OES. To accurately determine the Al and Ti contents in the MAO-Silica/FI catalytic systems, several toluene washing steps are performed during the MAO-Silica/FI preparation until the filtrate turned transparent to ensure complete removal of the MAO and FI catalyst physisorbed. The nitrogen adsorption/desorption and ICP analysis results are summarized in Table 2. As depicted in Fig. 2a and b, the nitrogen adsorption and desorption isotherms of MAO-mesoporous silicas (S1, S2) and MAO-spherical silicas (S3, S4) show type IV hysteresis loop, which reflects occurrence of the capillary condensation in the pores [32]. The pore size is intensely distributed around 1.5 nm in MAO-mesoporous silica and widely distributed from 4 to 9 nm, while MAO-S1 shows broader distribution than MAO-S2, which is due to the larger pore size of S1. MAO-S4 shows higher nitrogen adsorption and desorption isotherm in the higher relative pressure (0.4–0.8) as shown in Fig. 2b, which reflects larger amount of nitrogen molecules required for filling of the pores. Moreover, MAO-S4 shows higher intensity of the pore distribution from 5 to 16 nm in Figure 2b’, which suggests a broader pore range in MAO-S4 compared with the MAO-S3. The MAO-S5 (Fig. 2c) shows type I nitrogen adsorption and desorption isotherm, which is normally observed from microporous solid, having pore size approximately 0.1–2 nm (Figure 2c’). These results are in agreement with the different porous structure in the three type of silica. After grafting the MAO, a decreased surface area is measured from MAO-Silica. Particularly striking is the significant decrease of the surface area measured for MAO-S2 (from 800 m2/g in S2 to 510 m2/g), which suggests the possible hindrance effect from the MAO to the pore channel. Thus, showing a similar pore size distribution and the same value of pore volumes 0.3 cm3/g as MAO-S1. The pore volume of 0.4 cm3/g in MAO-S4 is higher than the pore volume of 0.3 cm3/g in MAO-S3, though the surface area of the two is similar. The volume difference in the similar surface area of the co-catalyst suggests the lower density of the pore size (5 to 16 nm) distribution in MAO-S3, implying lesser amount of the bigger pore in MAO-S3. Using the same MAO grafting procedure on the different silica, MAO-mesoporous silica (MAO-S1, MAO-S2 13.7 wt.% and 9.8 wt.% respectively) show the lowest Al content compared to MAO-spherical silica (MAO-S3, MAO-S4 14.5 wt.% and 17.0 wt.% respectively) and MAO-nano silica (MAO-S5, 16.4 wt.%). Considering the higher surface area in mesoporous silicas, the different Al content can be mainly attributed to the different frame structure of these silicas. Mesoporous silica (S1, S2) is characterized by a porous structure (as noted in the SEM images shown in Figure S3) and MAO-mesoporous silica show a low Al content, denoting a lower amount of MAO grafted. It is reasonable to think that MAO cannot easily penetrate into the pores and reacting with the reactive groups present in the inner channels [33,34], leading to a lower Al content. While S3 and S4, characterized as a “smooth-surface” structure, can provide comparably more reacting surface to the MAO leading to an increased Al content and there is only a slightly change of the surface area. Unexpectedly, S5 has the lowest surface area but shows the second highest Al content of all the MAO-grafted silicas, bringing the unneglectable interest on the nano silica, having smallest particle size and lowest surface area while having a good Al loading amount. The results of Al content in MAO-Silicas obtained from ICP-OES analysis shows a good match with the independent results estimated from EDS and XPS measurements (both measurement give less accurate elementary amount information compared to ICP) as summarized in Table S4. In all cases, the MAO-Silicas show similar Al content compared to the MAO-Silica/FI, suggesting a stable chemical bonding (not physisorbed, which can leach after several washing) between the Silica and MAO. The reaction mechanism between MAO and Silica has been studied by Bashir and co-workers with 1H MAS NMR and FT-IR measurement, proposing the pathway as depicted in Scheme 2 top, the SiOSi opening happens upon reaction with the [Al]MAO-Me, resulting in SiO[Al]MAO and Si-Me [31]. Another reaction mechanism observed by Soga and co-workers upon reacting MAO with the silica involves the acid-base reaction between the silanol group with the Al[MAO]-Me as depicted in Scheme 2 bottom [35]. To understand the bonding between the Silica and the MAO, XPS measurements have been performed to measure the bonding energy of Si and O. For this purpose, S5 catalytic system has been used and the results are summarized in Fig. 3 . As shown in Fig. 3a, the bonding energy of Si from S5 is 104.0 eV, which is attributed to the Si surrounded by the O environment, HO(SiOn) [36,37]. After reacted with MAO, the bonding energy of Si from MAO-S5 shifts to lower bonding energy value at 102.9 eV. This shift may be due to the formation of AlO(SiOn) moieties, where Si center has increased electron density compared with HO(SiOn). Moreover, the bonding energy of O also presents a shift to lower bonding value as depicted in Fig. 3b. A decreased value of bonding energy of the O from 533.2 eV to 532.2 eV has been observed after silica reacted with MAO, which is corresponded to the bond formation of SiOAl from SiOH. The bonding energy of O from MAO is provided as a reference, showing the lowest value of bonding energy (531.8 eV) by the highest electron density around O from the OAl bond. Furthermore, the bubbles have been continuously observed during the reaction of silica and MAO, which is suggests the formation of methane gas by reaction of [MAO]Al-CH3 with SiOH. Therefore, according to the above discussion and results, the reaction formula between Silicas and MAO is concluded to follow the Scheme 2 bottom. 3.2 Polymerization results of MAO-Silica/FI catalytic systems The polymerization results from MAO-Silicas/FI catalysts prepared by dehydroxylating the silicas at 200 °C together with the thermal and rheological polymer characterization results are summarized in Table 3 . The homogenous polymerization shows higher yield and catalyst activity compared with heterogeneous polymerizations, with the highest yield of 72.6 g and the highest catalyst activity of 1941 KgPE*molTi −1*h−1*bar−1. The lower yield and catalyst activity in the heterogeneous polymerizations can arise from several factors, including but not limited to: 1) the presence of catalyst deactivating groups on the support, e.g. excess silanol groups 2) lower ability of the MAO to activate the catalyst due to a pre-reaction of active Al-Me groups with the silanol moieties on the silicas or change in the MAO structure upon anchoring 3) limitation of monomer transfer through the silica pores after anchoring the MAO and catalyst 4) slow or incomplete silica fragmentation during polymerization [19,20,21]. Using the same catalyst preparation and polymer synthesis procedure, yield for the heterogeneous catalytic systems present an increase in the order MAO-spherical silicas (S3, S4)/FI<MAO-mesoporous silicas (S2, S1)/FI<MAO-nano silica (S5)/FI, being 1.7, 2.2, 7.8, 8.4, 21.4 g respectively; followed the increased polymerization activity in MAO-S4/FI<MAO-S2/FI<MAO-S1/FI<MAO-S3/FI<MAO-S5/FI. Surprisingly, MAO-S3/FI gives a higher calculated polymerization activity compared with MAO-S4/FI, which mainly contribute to the highest Al/Ti ratio of 1413. Within the other catalytic systems, the highest catalyst activity is observed when using nano silica (MAO-S5/FI) with 618 KgPE*molTi −1*h−1*bar−1; while, the lowest yield and catalyst activity is observed for the spherical silica with (MAO-S4/FI) 127 KgPE*molTi −1*h−1*bar−1. As summarized in Table 1, MAO-S5/FI has the highest Ti content of 0.2 wt.%, followed by MAO-S1/FI, MAO-S2/FI, and MAO-S4/FI of 0.1 wt.%. However, the different in the catalyst activity (5 times) does not match the difference in titanium content (2 times) between MAO-S5/FI and MAO-S4/FI. On the contrary, it is interesting to notice that S5 has the lowest surface area while having similar Al amount anchored compared with S4, which suggests that the significant reduced free OH groups in S5 by MAO promotes the higher catalyst activity in MAO-S5. In mesoporous silicas, MAO-S1 and MAO-S2 having lower Al and metal content show the lower yield and activity compared with MAO-S5. S1 and S2 BET characterization result in porous size distribution around 1.5 nm and 4–9 nm, which is smaller than the pore size distribution of S4 around 5–16 nm. These smaller pores in S1 and S2 can potentially lead to a blockage of MAO in the pore channel compared to S3 and S4, resulting a comparable higher amount of Al loaded outside of the pore channel. Thus, MAO-S1 and MAO-S2 can probably provide more sufficient Al area outside of the pore for activating the metal sites, eventually giving a higher activity in MAO-mesoporous silicas/FI than MAO-spherical silicas/FI. This significant difference in terms of yield and catalyst activity between the heterogeneous catalytic systems MAO-spherical silicas/FI and MAO-nano silica/FI, considering the similar amount of Al and Ti detected, may be correlated to the different availability of the active sites in the different silicas used. In particular, when nano silica is used, considering the extreme low size, the active sites are readily exposed to MAO (for catalyst activation) and the monomer (for the catalysis). When using spherical or mesoporous silicas, the MAO can be modified to a less reactive species by an excessive amount of silanol group in combination with the presence of pores and channels, which limit the monomer diffusion. All the synthesized polymers have similar melting temperature around 141 °C, and crystallinity of 80%, in agreement with previous results obtained in similar conditions (homogeneous) using the same catalyst [6,10]. The Tm and χ values suggest that all the synthesized polymers using the heterogeneous catalytic systems have similar basic thermal properties compared with the polymer synthesized using the same catalyst (FI catalyst) in homogeneous conditions. The catalyst residuals have been determined by TGA at 500 °C. PE-MAO-spherical silicas (S3, S4)/FI has the highest percent of catalyst residual, 19.2% and 17.5%; followed by PE-MAO-mesoporous silicas (S1, S2)/FI with 3.9%, 5.1%; PE-MAO-nano silica (S5)/FI with 1.8%, and MAO/FI, 0.9%, in good agreement with the amount of inorganic catalyst used normalized by the polymer yield generated. The catalyst residuals from heterogeneous catalytic systems is mainly contributed by the silicas and alumina (from supported MAO); while for the homogeneous conditions, the residual is mainly formed by the alumina generated from the MAO. The molecular weights and polydispersities are estimated by rheological measurement, preferred over high-temperature gel permeation chromatography for molecular weights above 1–2 million g/mol due to the solubility issue of the latter [25,38]. Because of the large amount of silica left in PE-MAO-spherical silicas (S3, S4)/FI, the rheological measurement is heavily affected leading to inaccurate determination of the viscoelastic functions. Thus, only for the PE-MAO-mesoporous silicas (S1, S2)/FI, PE-MAO-nano silica (S5)/FI and PE-MAO/FI polymers, rheological measurements have been performed to determine the molecular characteristics. The molecular weights of the polymer synthesized are all well-over 1 million g/mol confirming the ability of the catalyst to produce UHMWPE in both homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysis using different silicas [10,16,17,18,19]. As summarized in Table 3, the molecular weight of the polymer synthesized in homogeneous conditions (PE-MAO/FI) is 9.1 × 106 g/mol, which is lower than PE-MAO-S5/FI, 11.8 × 106 g/mol and higher than PE-MAO-mesoporous silicas (S1, S2)/FI, 7.4 × 106 and 5.1 × 106 g/mol respectively; the higher molecular weight in PE-MAO-S5/FI is possibly attributed to the reduction of chain transfer towards alkyl aluminum due to the absence (or reduction) of trimethyl aluminum after MAO grafting [39,40]. A possible explanation for the lower molecular weight estimated for the polymers synthesized using the mesoporous silicas (S1, S2) could be attributed to 1) the hindrance of the monomer transfer to active site through the pore channels, limiting the chain growth compared with homogeneous and spherical and nano sized catalytic systems [19]; or due to 2) the termination by chain transferring to the excessive silanol groups. All the polymers from heterogeneous catalysts show a broader molecular weight distribution, compared with homogeneous catalyst, which can be attributed to the effect of the silica on the viscoelastic functions and/or as an effect of the poor monomer diffusion throughout the silicas pores [17,19,41]. The morphology of silicas, MAO-silicas and the resulting polymers (PE-MAO-silicas/FI) are probed by SEM and the images are displayed in Fig. 4 (lower magnification can be found in Figure S5). S1 and S2 present an irregular shape with sizes ranging from few tens of µm to hundreds of µm; S3 and S4 present a smooth surface and spherical morphology with an average particle size of 50–200 µm; S5 has a nano-size particles which tends to aggregate into particles with an estimated size in the order of few µm. After MAO-grafting, all the MAO-Silicas (as Figure 4a’-e’) show similar morphology and size as the starting silicas, which suggests no particles fragmentation and aggregation during the reaction with MAO. The resulting appearance of the polymer synthesized show morphology replication of the starting particles’ shape for the catalytic systems PE-MAO-mesoporous silicas (S1, S2)/FI, PE-MAO-spherical silicas (S3, S4)/FI. While for the PE-MAO-nano silica (S5)/FI there is no clear morphology duplication, moreover, the size of the polymer particle is different order of magnitude bigger compared to the initial starting catalytic system MAO-S5/FI. The absence of particle replication is most likely cause by the very small size of MAO-S5/FI (few µm) which is unable to provide sufficient surface to the polymer to nucleate and replicate the morphology. All the heterogeneous catalytic systems do not show reactor fouling and/or wall sheeting during and after polymerization, confirming the heterogeneous nature of the catalytic systems used (PE-MAO-silicas/FI). In contrast, reactor fouling and wall sheeting is observed when using single-site catalytic system in homogeneous conditions (entry 1). 3.3 Evaluation of entanglement formation in the synthesized polymers Entanglement formation of the polymers’ melt have been studied using rheological measurement upon melting of the nascent particles [6,8]. Commercial UHMWPE (purchased from Sigma-Aldrich; Mw : 2 × 106 g/mol, Ð: 13, by rheological measurement) was used as the reference for the entangled UHMWPE, which is compressed at 160 °C into a disk for rheological measurements. As shown in Fig. 5 a, all the synthesized UHMWPE show a continuous increase of the storage modulus (G’) as a function of time in the melt, which suggests a gradual formation of the entanglements in the melt [6,8,10]. On the contrary, the value of storage modulus in the commercial entangled UHMWPE is initially high (around 1.7 MPa) and barely changes with time. Most of the synthesized polymers show a very slow G’ build-up, without reaching the equilibrium state within the experimental time. This is in agreement with previous findings for low-entangled UHMWPE having very high Mw , which do not reach the equilibrium state even after days in the melt [6]. To recall, the starting point of the storage modulus build-up, once brought to the melt state, is related to the entangled state of the polymer produced; in particular, for a low starting value corresponds a low degree of entanglement [6,8–10]. The decreasing order of the starting point of the storage modulus for the polymers produced is PE-MAO-spherical silicas (S3, S4)/FI>PE-MAO-mesoporous silicas (S1, S2)/FI>PE-MAO/FI>PE-MAO-nano silica (S5)/FI. Hence, from a rheological point of view, the most and the least disentangled UHMWPEs produced using the catalytic systems tested appear to be PE-MAO-nano silica (S5)/FI and PE-MAO-spherical silicas (S3, S4)/FI respectively. For all the polymers synthesized, the frequency sweeps of Fig. 5b do not show crossover point of the viscoelastic functions within the frequency range measured (∼0.001 rad/s). This is in agreement with previous findings using the same catalytic systems in heterogeneous as well as homogeneous conditions (e.g. black curves in Fig. 5c) and are characteristic of high molar mass polymers having Mw above approximately 6 million g/mol [6]. To note, the polymer synthesized using the nano silica, shows a very similar rheological data compared to the homogeneously synthesized low entangled UHMWPE (Fig. 5c). For PE-MAO-spherical silicas (S3, S4)/FI, the significant amount of catalytic ashes affect the viscoelastic functions leading to a storage modulus well above 2 MPa in the oscillation time sweep (Fig. 5a) and high values of G’ and G” in the frequency sweep (Fig. 5b). Even though the chain dynamic of this polymer is influences by the catalytic ashes, the functional dependence is very similar to the other polymers synthesized. To support the rheological characterization on the initial entangled state of the nascent polymers, isothermal crystallization procedure is used to differentiate the ease in crystallization between the entangled and disentangled domains in the melt [27]. All the polymers have been firstly heated to 160 °C, and then cooled to 128 °C to isothermally crystallize for 3 h. To recall, during this isothermal crystallization step (step d–e in Scheme 1), the disentangled domains in the melt possess higher mobility and can easier nucleate and crystallize in an ordered fashion compared to the entangled domains which crystallize only upon cooling (step e–f in Scheme 1). With further heating to 160 °C, these two populations of crystals can melt at different melting temperatures, the former more ordered crystals melt at 140 °C, while the latter melt-crystallized crystals melt at 133 °C. Upon increasing time in the melt (step b-c in Scheme 1), more entangled domain are formed increasing the melting enthalpy of the peak at 133 °C at the expenses of the high melting temperature peak (140 °C) corresponding to the disentangled domains. The heating ramp curves (step g–h, in Scheme 1) after different annealing time in the melt (step b-c of Scheme 1) is provided in Figure S6. All the synthesized polymers show a high peak temperature around 140 °C from heating ramp g-h, which is attributed to the crystallization of the disentangled domain upon isothermal at 128 °C and a lower melting temperature peak around 133 °C, corresponding to the melt-crystallized portion of entangled crystals formed upon cooling to 50 °C [26]. In contrast, the fully entangled commercial UHMWPE, does not show obviously crystallization during the isothermal crystallization step, but can crystallize prominently upon cooling leading to lower melting temperatures of 131 °C. In the synthesized polymers, the increased area proportion of 133 °C of synthesized polymers with increasing annealing time at 160 °C are plotted in Fig. 6 a. According to previous findings, the reported crystallization kinetic of Fig. 6a are in agreement with the formation of entanglements as a function of time in the melt, leading to an increase of the low melting temperature enthalpy. In particular, the kinetic showed by the polymers synthesized using the mesoporous (S1, S2) and nano (S5) silicas show a slow isothermal crystallization kinetics, similar to the homogeneously synthesized UHMWPE. In contrast, the polymers synthesized using the spherical silicas (S3, S4), barely show a crystallization kinetic indicating a higher entangled state. Therefore, the DSC crystallization kinetics support the rheological characterization and confirm the synthesis of low entangled UHMWPE using the catalytic systems developed in this work. Furthermore, the area proportion of the low melting temperature peak (133 °C) increases with increasing time in the melt (Fig. 6a), suggesting the increased formation of entanglements; within the same time in the melt, PE-MAO-nano silica(S5)/FI is always located below other synthesized polymers, indicating a lower entangled state compared to other polymers. The starting point and the increase rate of the low melting temperature peak area at 133 °C follows the order: PE-MAO-nano silica(S5)<PE-MAO-mesoporous silicas (S1, S2)<PE-MAO/FI<PE-MAO-spherical silica (S3, S4)/FI, implying the order of entangled state as measured by their ability to crystallize. The same order in the disentangled state of the polymers produced has been determined by rheology, reinforcing the outcome of the physical characterization. It is important to note that in this comparison differences in molecular weights and effect of the catalytic ashes on the crystallization ability are not taken into account. Additional proof of the low entangled state in the synthesized polymers is the recurrence of the high melting temperature peak (plotted in Fig. 6b) observed after annealing in the melt for a long time followed by isothermal crystallization at 126 °C. To recall, the recurrence of the high melting temperature peak after the polymer has been molten and isothermally crystallize at 126 °C is a distinctive feature of originally disentangled UHMWPE arising from its heterogeneous melt persisting even after rheological equilibration [27]. Compared with the commercial UHMWPE, all the synthesized polymers show recurrence of the high melting temperature around 140 °C. While only a lower melt temperature of 135.5 °C can be observed from the same DSC protocol in commercial UHMWPE, as plotted in Fig. 6b. The recurrence of the high melting temperature peak at 140 °C for the polymers tested further confirms the disentangled formation in the synthesized polymers. The details of the isothermal characterization under annealing time 5 min of the polymers are summarized in Table 4 to evaluate the disentangled formation in the early melt stage and hence closer to the reactor nascent powder. From the results of heating ramp g-h from short time in the melt (5 min, Scheme 1, step b-c), PE-MAO-S5/FI has the highest proportion of the high peak area (90%), suggesting the largest portion of disentangled domain crystallizing upon isothermal step compared to other polymers, which implies the lowest entangled state in the nascent polymer. It seems reasonable to correlate the lowest entangled state for PE-MAO-S5/FI to the lowest particle size of the nano silica and its ability to support a limited amount of MAO per silica particle and consequently a lower number of catalytic sites, thus decreasing chain overlap (e.g. entanglements) during synthesis. The remaining polymers follow a decreased order of low-entangled state in the nascent polymer, PE-MAO-S2/FI>PE-MAO-S1/FI>PE-MAO/FI>PE-MAO-S3/FI >PE-MAO-S4/FI with peak areas of 60%, 55%, 38%, 12%, 9% respectively. Furthermore, the polymers synthesized from the heterogeneous catalytic systems can be easily compressed below the melting point (e.g. 125 °C) to test their solid-state processability. The tensile specimens made from PE-MAO-nano silica (S5)/FI and PE-MAO-mesoporous silicas (S1)/FI show a good draw-ability in the solid state below the melting point (Figure S7) further strengthening the DSC and rheological characterization of their lower entangled state. Furthermore, as illustrated in Fig. 7 , the nascent polymer particles of PE-MAO-nano silica (S5)/FI11 are firstly compressed at 130 °C under 130 bar for 30 min in a rectangular metal model to a sample bar (29.5 cm *1.6 mm * 30.2 mm). Followed by a rolling process at 130 °C under 20 bar with a rolling speed of 0.5 m/min, a rolled tape about 12 times longer than initial tape length (348 cm * 0.15 mm * 24.0 mm) can be prepared for further stretching. The stretching process has been performed at two temperatures 148 and 152 °C, with rolling-in speed of 0.15 m/min and rolling-out speed around 0.5 m/min with a torque around 22 Nm and stretching force ranging from 126 to 189 N using a stretching temperature of 148 °C and around 250 N using a stretching temperature of 152 °C. The resulting mechanical properties summarized in Fig. 7 are reported for the two stretching temperatures used during the last stretching step. In particular, the black squares and the red circles represent the mechanical properties of the tape processed at 148 °C and 152 °C respectively. The tested tape with a draw ratio around 260 having average thickness of 34 μm, shows the maximum tensile strength of 3.26 N/tex (density of 0.7615 g/cm3, corresponding to 2.48 GPa) and tensile modulus of 170 N/tex (corresponding to 129 GPa) [42]. The tensile test results as a function of draw ratio are summarized in Fig. 7 while the stress-strain curves are reported in Figure S8. This solid-state processability of the low-entangled polymer synthesized from heterogeneous catalytic condition enhances the unneglectable influence of the dis-entangled morphology on processing the polymer for the outstanding properties. 3.4 Effect of silica-modifiers on the entangled state of the polymers Inspired by previous studies on the effect of large modifier (POSS) on the silica particle, we were intrigued in understanding the effect of smaller silanes on the catalytic effect and the entangled state of the resulting polymers. For this reason, two silanes modifier are reacted with the silica used prior to MAO grafting [17–21]. Ethyltrimethyoxysilane is used as a small modifier (sm), and octadecyltrichlorosilane as a big modifier (bm) in order to functionalize the silica surface and steer the MAO grafting towards different chemical environments (Scheme 3 ) [43–47]. S1, S4 and S5 have been selected as the candidates based on above discussion for the further study. The modified silicas were named as smSilicas (modified by the small ethyltrimethyoxysilane) and bmSilicas (modified by the bigger octadecyltrichlorosilane). Due to the small amount of modifiers, there was no appreciable difference observed at the FT-IR spectra of the silicas and mSilicas, as shown in Figure S9. The MAO grafting and the catalytic system preparation are performed in the same conditions as MAO-Silicas/FI and all the polymerizations are performed in the same conditions. The polymerization results and the thermal characterization are summarized in Table 5 . The modification of the silicas significantly influenced the polymeric yield of the catalyst systems (as ploted in Fig. 8 ), resulting in a decreased polymer yield. In particular, for the S5 silica system, the yield decresed from 21.0 g (PE- MAO-S5/FI) to 4.0 g (PE- MAO-smS5/FI) and 11.5 g (PE- MAO-bmS5/FI) using a small and big silane modifier respectively. However, a slightly yield increase is measured in MAO-smS4/FI with a yield of 2.6 g, compared with MAO-S4/FI of 2.2 g. All the synthesized polymers show a high melting temperature of 140–141 °C, and the crystallinity around 79% as discussed above. The lowest crystallinity of 66% from PE- MAO-bmS4/FI is most likely related to a large silica content in the polymer, leading to an uncorrect normalization of the melting enthalpy. All the catalyst residuals have been determined by TGA at 500 °C. The results are summarized in Table 5. Due to the large silica content in the catalyst systems from S4, the rheological characterization on the polymer PE-MAO-mS4/FI did not yield reliable results. The oscillatory time sweeps experiments on the PE-MAO-mSilicas/FI can be found in Fig. 9 a. All the oscillatory time sweep of the polymers produced show a relative low starting point of the storage modulus and a slow build-up as a function of time, indicating a lower amount of entanglements in the nascent powder. The higher starting values of the storage modulus are observed when the modifiers are used in comparison to the polymer synthesized using the catalytic systems without modifiers. In particular, when a small silane modifier is used, a slightly lower starting value of the elastic modulus is observed compared to the use of a large silane modifier. To complement the rheological characterization, the evolution of the entanglement formation in the polymers are also studied by isothermal crystallization DSC protocols as previous discussion. The area proportion of the low melting temperature peak (133 °C, from step g-h in Scheme 1) of synthesized polymers has been plotted as a function of annealing time, as summarized in Fig. 10 . In all cases, the enthalpy of the lower melting peak increases at the expenses of the enthalpy of the higher melting peak, showing increased proportion of lower melting temperature peak with increased annealing time at 160 °C (details shown in Figure S10). The observed melting kinetics is associated to the formation of entanglements upon melting, thus, implying the synthesis of low entangled UHMWPE. Comparing the melting kinetics of PE-MAO-smSilica/FI and PE-MAO-bmSilica/FI polymers with PE-MAO-Silica/FI polymers, it shows that the area of the high melting temperature decreases faster for the polymers synthesized using the silanes modifiers compared to those synthesized without modifiers, showing in Fig. 10. These findings are in good agreement with the rheological characterization of the same polymers, which suggests a lower entanglement formation in PE-MAO-Silica/FI. There is no significant effect in decreasing the number of entanglement formed during the polymer synthesis found in the modified-silica catalytic systems, which may be attributed to the aggregation of MAO in the vicinity modifier on the silica surface. The modifiers actually provide the possibility to reduce the distance between the active sites instead of enlarging the distance in the catalytic systems used. 4 Conclusions In this work, we have synthesized low-entangled UHMWPE using heterogeneous catalytic systems which consist of different silicas (S1, S2: mesoporous silica; S3, S4: Spherical silica; S5: silica nanopowder) having different features (i.e. surface area, pore size, dimension) where the catalyst activator MAO is supported and the FI catalyst (bis[N-(3-tert-butylsalicydene)-2,3,4,5,6-pentafluoroanilinato] titanium(IV) dichloride) is used. Silicas’ features are correlated to the catalytic performances and the entangled state of the polymers produced (Scheme 4). The MAO-grafted silicas have showed a decreased surface area determined by nitrogen adsorption and desorption analysis. The amount of Al and Ti in the catalytic systems have been determined by ICP-OES measurement. An increased Al amount after exposure of the silicas to the MAO has been found in the order MAO-S4>MAO-S3>MAO-S5>MAO-S1>MAO-S2, showing the sufficient influence of the different silicas’ structure on the grafting of MAO. The amount of Al in the MAO-grafted silicas (MAO-Silicas) is similar as the catalytic systems (MAO-Silicas/FI), suggesting a stable chemical grafting between the silicas and MAO. Furthermore, the bond between the silica and the MAO has been studied by XPS finding that the bonding energy of Si shifts from 104 eV to 102.9 eV, potentially suggesting a transformation of the bond HO-(Si-On) to AlO-(Si-On); while the O bonding energy shifts from 533.2 eV to 532.2 eV, further supporting the bond formation of Si-O-Al from Si-O-H as the conventional bond between Silica and MAO. These results, together with the formation of bubbles, are in agreement with a reaction between the silanol groups and the methyl groups on the MAO to form methane and (MAO)Al-O-Si(silica), as showed in Scheme 2 bottom. By the means of supporting the catalyst on the different silicas (heterogeneous catalytic system), the polymerization reaction show no reactor fouling and the morphology of the synthesized polymers, as observed by SEM, shown good replication of the silica morphology. A decreased polymer yield has been measured when using heterogeneous catalytic systems (compared to the homogeneous conditions). Several reasons could be responsible to the lower activity measured, being 1) the presence of catalyst deactivating groups on the support, e.g. excess silanol groups 2) lower ability of the MAO to activate the catalyst due to a pre-reaction of active Al-Me groups with the silanol moieties on the silicas or change in the MAO structure upon anchoring 3) limitation of monomer transfer through the silica pores after anchoring the MAO and catalyst 4) slow or incomplete silica fragmentation during polymerization. Unfortunately, based on the experimental results reported herein, it is not possible at this stage to identify the cause. Characterization of the synthesized polymers suggest a weakly entangled state based on the low starting values of the storage modulus and their build-up as a function of time in the melt as observed in the melt-rheology. Rheological characterization are supported by the presence of two melting peaks with variable areas as a function of time in the melt as observed by DSC. Thanks to the hindrance effect from the pore structure of the mesoporous silica; the polymer chains growing from MAO-S1/FI catalytic system have less entanglements formed compared with the polymer chains from MAO-S4/FI. Melt-rheology provides also an estimation of the Mw and Ð indicating that MAO-S5/FI, MAO-S1/FI and MAO-S2/FI are capable to promote the synthesis of UHMWPE having 11.9 × 106, 7.4 × 106 and 5.1 × 106 g/mol with a broad Ð of 8.3, 9.4 and 10.2 respectively. To further strengthening the low entangled state, solid-state processability of the nascent reactor powder is performed for the polymer synthesized by MAO-S5/FI (Fig. 7). PE-MAO-S5/FI shows the lowest value of G’ at the initial stages of the polymer melt among the synthesized polymers. The lowest entangled state of the polymer PE-MAO-S5/FI makes the polymer synthesized suitable for solid-state processing. The solid-state processing results shows that this polymer can be stretched to high draw ratios with a relative low stretching force to achieve high tensile strength (3.26 N/tex) and tensile modulus (170 N/tex). Furthermore, the use of silanes modifier can significantly influence the catalyst activity of the catalytic systems studied resulting in a decreased yield for S1 and S5; while the activity has been slightly improved in S4 catalytic system. The entangled state of the nascent polymers is also studied by rheology and DSC indicating the synthesis of low entangled polymers with slightly higher entanglement density per chain compared to the scenario without using silanes modifiers. This is potentially related to the agglomeration of MAO supported in the close vicinity of the modifiers, thus reducing the active site distance. coredata.dc:description: Different types of silica (mesoporous, spherical and nano-size particles), pre-activated with methylaluminoxane (MAO), are used to activate and support the bis[N-(3‑tert-butylsalicydene)-2,3,4,5,6-pentafluoroanilinato] titanium(IV) dichloride (FI) complex with the aim to synthesize low-entangled UHMWPE having controlled particle morphology. Through the porosity analysis, nitrogen adsorption and desorption isotherms, a decreased surfaced area of the chosen silica is observed when supported by MAO. From the bonding energy study by XPS, the bonding energy difference of Si and O, between the nano-size silica and in the MAO-nano silica, suggests the formation of Al-O-Si after chemical activation with MAO. Using elementary analysis, ICP-OES and XPS characterization, the aluminum content grafted on the silica surface is found to match with the anticipated amount of MAO on the MAO-Silica/FI catalytic system, indicating a stable grafting after catalyst supporting. From the rheological studies of the polymers, coupled with DSC results using an isothermal crystallization protocol, the resultant entangled state in the semi-crystalline polymers is estimated. The observations are that the entangled state achieved during polymerization from the investigated heterogeneous catalytic systems, is the lowest in PE-MAO-nano silica/FI, increases in PE-MAO-mesoporous silica/FI and is highest in PE-MAO-spherical silica/FI. Silica modification using two different silanes shows significant influence on the catalytic activity, giving lower polymer yield in MAO-modified-mesoporous silica and MAO-modified-nano silica compared to the unmodified MAO-silica. Whereas, no significant spatial effect is observed in the formation of chain entanglement, showing the increased entanglement density of the nascent polymers. By employing heterogeneous catalytic systems, reactor fouling and wall sheeting problems are resolved and the polymers show good morphology replication of the support. The UHMWPE synthesized using the nano silica as support, having the lowest entangled state and loosely packed crystals, can be uniaxially processed in the solid-state to a thin tape having thickness around 34 μm, showing maximum tensile strength of 3.26 N/tex and tensile modulus of 170 N/tex.
coredata.dc:title: Silica-supported catalyst for the synthesis of low entangled UHMWPE suitable for solid-state processing
